messageBody:
2008/6/9 J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...>:
> On 2008-06-09, at 07:23 , Phil Surette wrote:
>> ... it's often the case that the
>> first time you see the message for an assertion will be when the
>> assertion fails, which may not happen until you run a regression test
>> many moons after you coded the test. Unless you see the message
>> displayed when you are developing the test, you won't realize that the
>> message - if you provided one - is not be very helpful. Better
>> assertion messages also help to communicate to a developer what the
>> point of the assertion is both when it fails and when reading the
>> test.
>>
> If you aren't going to think about the failure message when you write
> it, then don't write one.

This sounds more like a process problem and logging won't do anything
to help solve that.

The first time you see a failure message should be when you are
writing the test. You should always watch the test fail to ensure
that it is actually testing what you think it's testing and that the
diagnostic messages clearly describe the failure.

If you're programming test-first, then the test will almost always
fail when you write it. Testing the test and improving the diagnostics
is very easy.

If I have to write tests after the fact, I first make the test check
for incorrect expected values and then, when I have the test failing
correctly with good diagnostics, I fix it to check for the real
expected values.

--Nat
